awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Strengthening Metallic Nanofoams Through Ligament Scale Materials Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanoscale metal foams exhibit several remarkable properties. The most common nanostructured foams are currently made of pure metals, and they demonstrate exceptional performance in areas such as catalysis, batteries, and optics. These metal foams are, however, often fragile and difficult to integrate into engineering applications. The ability to mechanically strengthen foams to create robust materials has heretofore been limited in pure metals. This award supports research aimed at creating a new class of materials - composite nano foams - which display the same remarkable properties as pure metal foams, but with significantly enhanced structural integrity. The new materials designed through this work will allow researchers and engineers to exploit unique properties without suffering failure during mechanical handling or service. The fundamental knowledge gained from this research may be used in designing and manufacturing catalysts with low cost and high strength, fuel cells with higher capacity and faster charging times, biomedical implants with high fatigue resistance, and lighter and stronger hydrogen storage units. A team of researchers at two universities, Clarkson and Purdue, will carry out this work, exposing students at both schools to the increasingly common long-distance collaborations needed for advancing research. 

The research team will couple computational methods of materials engineering at the atomistic and mesoscopic scales (molecular dynamics and finite element analysis) to experimental methods of manufacturing and characterizing composite nanostructured foams. The working hypothesis is that coating individual foam ligaments with nanostructure multilayers will result in the formation of stronger foams. To create these materials, copper and nickel will be electroplated to form core-shell layers on templates of paper-like mats of eletrospun polymers, which will be oxidized and then subsequently reduced to form nanoscale copper metal wires. Pulsed-laser thermoelastic excitation will be used to determine the dispersion and vibrational resonance to obtain the foam's bulk elastic properties. These results will be compared directly to finite element simulations of the composite to isolate the effects of geometry and ligament properties. Foam strength will be predicted based on molecular dynamics simulations of the ligaments, which will provide information to feed into the finite element models, and finally compared to experimental studies of the yield strength using nanoindentation with a flat punch geometry. The intellectual significance of this work will be the development of a new class of materials guided by computational materials engineering, and the development of novel techniques for manufacturing and testing nanoscale metallic foams.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The nanoporous metal foams represent the ultimate form factor of metals for high surface area and catalytic applications. This research included a combination of simulations and experiments to fundamentally understand the deformation mechanisms of nanofoam ligaments made of more than one metal and guiding the industry and academia in designing and manufacturing low-cost and high strength foams for catalysts, fuel cells, implants, and hydrogen storage units. First, composite ligaments consisting of two and three different metallic alternating layers were studied. The results suggested that a significant gain in hardness can be achieved over single metal ligaments. Furthermore, the results revealed a close relationship between the atomic composition of the ligament and its hardening. Comparison with experimental findings showed strong similarities with nanopillars made of the same materials. Also, as metallic nanofoams are formed from interconnected networks of ligaments spanning various length scales, a multiscale computational approach has been developed to study their macroscopic behavior. This approach combined atomistic simulations with finite elements to link the nano to the macro scales. The atomistic simulations were used to find the yield surface of a representative unit cell structure, which then was transferred to the finite element model to study the macroscopic behavior of the nanofoams. The simulated mechanical conduct of copper nanofoams was found to be in good agreement with actual experimental results. The developed methodology is straightforward and well documented. As such, it can be used in other applications where the contribution from multiple length scales is essential since it is not restricted to metallic nanofoams only.

To demonstrate this, we applied the methodology to study the mechanical properties of copper-nickel alloyed nanofoams manufactured by electrospinning and subsequent thermal processing. An ultrasonic testing apparatus utilizing both surface acoustic wave and bulk waves in granular media was also developed for the non-destructive test of the mechanical properties of nanofoams. The experimental results suggest that adding the alloying element (in this case, nickel) increases the hardening of the nanofoams. The simulation modeling agreed qualitatively with the experiments and found that the experimentally observed behavior is related to the addition of solute atoms that prevent the free dislocation movement and increase the strength of the structure. This behavior is not restricted to copper-nickel alloys, and it can be used for other material combinations for specific applications. Furthermore, the manufacturing of alloyed nanofoams is more straightforward and, therefore, more advantageous for obvious reasons. Finally, the effect of complexity on the mechanical behavior and recovery of metallic nanoarchitecture structures made of metallic nano-ligaments was investigated. We introduced a methodology to calculate the complexity of architected nanostructures that can be applied to other materials. We linked this complexity to the recovery ability, strength, geometric cell size, and temperature of these structures. These findings can guide the design of novel nanoarchitecture geometries for specific applications with tailored properties.

In conclusion, the results of this research suggested developing a new class of metal nanofoams with the potential to fully exploit such materials' capabilities without suffering failure during mechanical handling or service. Finally, this project offered undergraduate students and graduate researchers ample opportunities to participate in an emerging area of research. It provided them with a significantly broader experience than would be realized in a traditional curriculum.


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Ioannis Mastorakos
